economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over grain theft during famine years (1636-1638). Lawsuit over field 4-5 years before trial. Dispute over planks from ruined house. Dispute over iron chain and field set on fire. Trial costs included 24 francs for beating 24 resaulx of grain (6 wheat, 2 rye, 16 oats) suggesting grain confiscation. General context of economic hardship with famine, grain rotting in fields, soldiers taking harvested grain.

extraction_metadata.notes: This trial features unusual dynamics: the son Demenge's testimony was central but highly unstable - he made initial claims, recanted multiple times, changed his story about whether parents attended sabbat, and was released along with his mother. The trial reveals significant economic hardship context with famine years 1636-1638 driving grain theft disputes. Martin made counter-accusations of theft against multiple witnesses. Two deceased wives' statements (reported by witness) suggested long-standing reputation. The devil figure is referred to as 'violon' (minstrel/fiddler) who transported people on horns and gave grease for malefice. Community fear was palpable - inhabitants threatened to abandon the village if witches not removed. Costs of 707 francs included confiscated grain. Uncertainty: exact dates of some events (torture date estimated), number and names of all 62 witnesses (only 22 confronted are named), specific confession details not recorded in summary.
